Task.TaskDescription: Problem: Shane and Shawn manage a widget store. Shawn is the saleperson, and she is very good. However many widgets are in stock, she manages to sell 25% of them each week. It's Shane's job to make sure the number of widgets in stock is around 100, which means Shawn would sell about 25 widgets a week. However, while Shane was sick, the widget stock dropped to 25 widgets. Although the current widget deficit is 75, and Shawn wants him to order that many, Shane is conservative. He decides the number of widgets he will order and add to stock each week will be 30% of the deficit each week until the deficit is gone. Goal: Graph the number of widgets in stock for 20 weeks.
Task.ShortDescription:
The number of widgets in stock at the end of the week = 
 the number of widgets in stock at the end of the previous week 
 + the number of widgets added to stock this week 
 - the number of widgets removed from stock this week. 
 Initially, the number of widgets in stock is 25. 
the number of widgets removed from stock each week = 
 the proportion of the stock sold during the week 
 * the number of widget in stock at the beginning of the week. 
the proportion of the stock sold during each week is given at 0.25. 
The number of widgets added to stock each week = 
 the proportion of the stock deficit added each week 
 * the stock deficit this week. 
the proportion of the stock deficit added each week is given at 0.3. 
the stock deficit each week = 
 the number of widgets that should be in stock this week 
 - the number of widgets in stock this week 
the number of widgets that should be in stock each week is given as 100. 
the number of widgets that Shawn should sell a week is given as 25 (extra) 
the number of widgets in the stock after Shane was sick is given as 25 (extra) 	he number of widget deficit on the first week is given as 75 (extra) 	he number of widget Shawn wants Shane to reorder on the first week is given as 75 (extra)
